elements.text: PART ONE
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
1. INT. WAKEFIELD’S HOUSE, LIVING ROOM
MIDDLE-CLASS VICTORIAN HOME. CLOCK ON MANTEL. LOW FIRE.
You are asleep, Mr Wakefield?
(BEAT. TRANCE-LIKE) Yes...
Excellent. You see, Edward? He sleep-wakes still.
Yes, Sir.
And I believe we are still in mesmeric rapport. Mr Wakefield? You will please... hop on one leg.
Certainly, Mr Peabody.
WAKEFIELD BEGINS HOPPING.
Ha. Excellent.
Very good, sir.
Thank you, Mr Wakefield. You may stop now.
WAKEFIELD STOPS.
PEABODY (CONT’D) You may sit.
WAKEFIELD SITS.
PEABODY (CONT’D) So. To recapitulate... You fully understand Club rules?
(TRANCE) Yes.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 3
You will adhere to them at all times?
I will.
And most particularly...?
When I set foot within the Club building.
And our Queen. To her you will hold...?
Unalterable, unswerving allegiance.
Go on.
I will do her bidding. I will remain always ready for the summons to her cause.
And when that summons arrives?
I will serve her loyally... even unto death. I will forever serve the Red Queen!
Excellent! Then it is time to wake you.
PEABODY PASSES HIS HANDS RAPIDLY OVER WAKEFIELD. MUSIC FX.
And... with a few simple passes... Mr Wakefield?
Mmmm... ?
Wake now, sir. Wake, I say.
(WAKING) Mmmm. What?
PEABODY CEASES HIS MOVEMENTS.
Ah! There! You feel well, sir?
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 4
Certainly, Mr Peabody. Shall we begin?
Bless me, the initiation is over, Mr Wakefield. (TO EDWARD) Get my coat, Edward. We must return to the Club.
Very good, sir.
EDWARD EXITS.
Over?
Yes.
Remarkable! I wasn’t aware of... anything! So then I anm...?
Oh, yes. Yes indeed! It is my privilege, as Club Secretary, to
welcome you as a new brother. You have attained full membership of London’s premier Gentlemen’s society. You are most welcome,
sir, to the ranks of.. The Contingency Club!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 5
2. INT. TARDIS, CONTROL ROOM
THE DOCTOR TAPS DATA INTO THE TARDIS’ CONSOLE WHICH BEEPS IN RESPONSE.
Mm-hmm. Good...
NYSSA ENTERS.
What are you doing, Doctor? Inputting co-ordinates?
(CONCENTRATING) Trying to... yes.
Why? Where are we going?
Patience, Nyssa. You’ll see. Where’s Tegan?
In her room. With Adric. She was showing us some of her things from Earth.
Mmm.
Why do you ask?
(ABSORBED) No reason. I just need a moment to concentrate. I want to get this right...!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 6
3. INT. TARDIS, TEGAN’S ROOM
ADRIC IS FIDDLING WITH A 1980S WALKMAN.
I don’t understand.
Don’t understand what? I’ve explained it. The music is stored on the tape.
I know, but -
- Here. Pass it over.
SHE TAKES THE WALKMAN FROM ADRIC.
You put the cassette in here... See?
SHE PUTS A TAPE IN.
TEGAN (CONT’D) Press play...
SHE CLICKS THE WALKMAN ON. TINNY MUSIC COMES OUT.
TEGAN (CONT’D) And you can listen to music. Wherever you are.
I know, but -
- It’s small, you see? Compact. Perfect for a travelling stewardess! I thought you’d be interested, Adric! This is high tech.
Hardly.
Well you’re the one who said you didn’t understand.
I understand the technology, Tegan. Magnetic tape? Quite primitive really.
What...?
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 7
But what I don’t understand, is why you’d store music on it. Why not store something useful?
Like what? Quadratic equations?
If you like.
Adric! Didn’t you have music on Alzarius?
I never really had time for it.
Some teenager you are!
Well, don’t get offended.
Oh, forget it. I’m going to find the others.
SHE WALKS OUT OF THE ROOM.
What did I say now?
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 8
4. INT. TARDIS, CONTROL ROOM
THE DOCTOR FLICKS A FEW SWITCHES.
Nearly there...!
Then tell me. Where are we going, Doctor?
HE FLICKS THE LAST ONE WITH A FLOURISH.
Heathrow! England!
Doctor... I’m not so sure Tegan still wants to go back there.
Really-?
INTERIOR DOOR. TEGAN WALKS IN.
Someone get me out of this place!
What’s Adric done now?
ADRIC WALKS IN.
I didn’t do anything! Apart from say her personal cassette player was primitive and pointless.
TEGAN SHAKES THE WALKMAN AT HIM.
This cost me a small fortune! I treated myself when I got my job with the airline. And it is not primitive! Tell him, Doctor!
Well... these things are relative, Tegan.
What?
You see?
Well, all I can say, is that Alzarius must have been pretty boring if you never enjoyed a bit of music!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL)
We had more important things to do!
Please! Both of you! We’re about to land.
At Heathrow?
Even Nyssa sounds sceptical now.
Page 9
In my opinion, we've tried and failed a bit too often.
So you’ve made it a personal challenge?
I’ve been wondering — what if some kind of influence were
deliberately keeping us away?
Or perhaps you just can’t fly this bucket of bolts.
SUDDENLY THE TARDIS TILTS AND PLUNGES DOWNWARD!
DOCTOR, NYSSA, TEGAN AND ADRIC
CRY OUT — THROWN ABOUT
See?!
Doctor, what’s happening?!
THE DOCTOR CLAMBERS BACK TO THE CONSOLE.
We're... falling!
What?
Is that possible?!
It shouldn’t be!
DOCTOR, NYSSA, TEGAN AND ADRIC
THROWN ABOUT AGAIN
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 10
5. EXT. LONDON STREET, OUTSIDE THE CONTINGENCY CLUB
A HORSE DRAWN CARRIAGE PULLS UP OUTSIDE THE CLUB.
Whoa!
THE HORSES HALT. PEABODY, WAKEFIELD AND EDWARD ALIGHT.
Thank you, driver. [HE HANDS HIM A COUPLE OF COINS] That will be all.
Very good, sir. Gee there!
HORSES NEIGH. THE CARRIAGE PULLS OFF.
And here we are.
Magnificent, sir! The most splendid Club building in all St James's!
Wait until you see the interior, sir. Shall we?
THEY CROSS THE STREET TO THE CLUB ENTRANCE. GEORGE AUGUSTUS APPROACHES.
AUGUSTUS (OFF) (CALLING) Mr Peabody! Good day, sir!
(ANNOYED) Ah... Mr Augustus...
How do you do, sir!
Ah, I’m afraid, Mr Augustus, we are rather pressed for -
- And who is this? A new addition to your hallowed number?
(SIGHS) May I introduce Mr Wakefield, the noted natural scientist. But if you would please excuse us...?
Mr Wakefield, sir! Delighted.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 11
(CONFUSED) And I, sir.
I am George Augustus. You may have heard of me?
I don’t believe -
- I am a writer.
A journalist.
I know of your reputation of course! No wonder the Contingency Club has ushered you into its ranks!
Please, sir. You really must excuse us.
PEABODY, WAKEFIELD AND EDWARD PRESS ON UP THE STEPS.
I was hoping I might just -
- (CALLING BACK) No, thank you. Another time perhaps.
PEABODY KNOCKS ON THE CLUB DOOR.
PEABODY (CONT ’D) (SOFT) Edward, make sure Mr Augustus remains outside.
Very good, sir.
THE DOOR OPENS. PEABODY AND WAKEFIELD ENTER.
(FOLLOWING) Really, Mr Peabody, sir! Just a moment of your time!
THE DOOR SHUTS.
I am very sorry, sir. Entry is for Club members only.
(NOT HAPPY) Yes. Yes, of Course.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 12
6. INT. TARDIS, CONTROL ROOM
EVERYONE IS STILL HANGING ON FOR DEAR LIFE AND CRYING OUT. SUDDENLY - A MASSIVE BUMP! EVERYONE FALLS.
Oooof!
PAUSE. THE TARDIS IS NOW EERILY QUIET - NO SOUNDS AT ALL. COMPLETELY SHUT DOWN.
Everyone all right?
Yes.
Ow. Yes.
I’m not promising something’s not broken.
Doctor, what happened?
Why’s there no light?
I can’t see a thing!
THE DOCTOR GETS TO HIS FEET, AND GROPES ACROSS THE CONSOLE FLICKING SWITCHES.
The TARDIS has completely shut down...! Here, I think I have
THE DOCTOR FEELS IN HIS POCKETS.
DOCTOR (CONT’D) Yes!
HE PULLS OUT A POCKET TORCH AND CLICKS IT ON.
You carry a torch in your pocket?
Don’t you?
We’ve landed?
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 13
You can’t call that a landing?
THE DOCTOR FLICKS MORE SWITCHES.
It’s like we just... fell out of the vortex.
Fell?
We were close to our destination then the TARDIS.. shut itself down!
So where are we?
I don’t know, Adric. I can’t use any of the instruments!
We can’t even open the scanner?
THE DOCTOR TRIES.
No. Nothing! Dead!
So we could be anywhere.
Well, not anywhere, Tegan. We were en route to Heathrow in 1981.
So you say.
Maybe the old girl’s protecting herself for some reason... We’1l have to look outside.
THE DOCTOR WALKS TO THE HAT STAND, GETS HIS COAT.
Outside? We don’t know what’s out there! The atmosphere could be poisonous!
I keep telling you, Tegan. We’1ll be on Earth. Somewhere near Heathrow, close to 1981. Apart from a growing hole in the Ozone layer, we'll be fine.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 14
Well forgive me if I don’t share your confidence.
You never do.
TEGAN WAVES HER WALKMAN AROUND.
You know my cassette player here might be primitive. But at least it’s technology that consistently does what it’s supposed to. And that’s more than you can say for the TARDIS!
THE DOCTOR MARCHES OVER AND TAKES THE WALKMAN.
I’1ll take that, thank you.
Hey! What are you doing?
Confiscating it. It’s already been the cause of one argument between you and Adric. Now you’re using it to insult my TARDIS!
Doctor, you’re not our headmaster!
Well sometimes you could all do with one! You can have it back once we’ve looked outside.
HE PUTS THE WALKMAN IN HIS POCKET.
How do we even get the door open?
Ah... yes...
HE WALKS TO DOOR.
DOCTOR (CONT’D) There’s an emergency release somewhere...
HE WORKS ON A NEARBY PANEL.
DOCTOR (CONT’D) Adric, help me get this panel off.
But, Doctor... if something made the TARDIS shut down... there might be danger out there. Tegan might have a point this time.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page
This time?
THE DOCTOR AND ADRIC GET THE PANEL OPEN.
Ah! Thank you, Adric.
HE PULLS A LEVER INSIDE. THE DOOR HISSES OPEN.
DOCTOR (CONT’D) There! Open! Well?
I’m not going out.
I’1l wait with Tegan, Doctor.
Adric?
I’'1l come.
Good.
Leave the torch with us?
THE DOCTOR HANDS THE TORCH TO NYSSA.
There you are. Come along, Adric.
HE EXITS THE TARDIS.
Back soon.
ADRIC FOLLOWS THE DOCTOR OUT.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 16
7. INT. THE CONTINGENCY CLUB, GALLERY, CONTINUOUS
THE DOCTOR AND ADRIC STEP CAUTIOUSLY OUT OF THE TARDIS.
Well, we’re not suffocating. So the air must be breathable.
Like I said. Why does she never listen to me?
THEY WALK FORWARD ON A WOODEN FLOOR.
But what is this place?
Some sort of stately home? It’s Earth, anyway. And a rather fine collection of portraits!
At least there’s light out here.
A little dated for the nineteen-eighties..! Could just be an house, of course.
ADRIC WALKS TO A LAMP ON THE WALL.
I don’t understand this light, Doctor. It’s not electric...
THE DOCTOR WALKS OVER TO ADRIC.
Gaslight. Ah. Not very nineteen-eighties at a1l..
Shall I tell the others it’s safe to come out?
Oh... yes. Why not?
ADRIC WALKS BACK TO THE TARDIS.
DOCTOR (CONT ’D) Gaslight...?
HE WALKS ALONG THE GALLERY.
DOCTOR (CONT'D)
old
If only you portraits could talk. [Of course, that only really
happens in the whispering galleries of Icaria Beta...]
OVER THIS, EDWARD'S FOOTSTEPS APPROACH DOWN THE GALLERY.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 17
EDWARD (OFF) Sir?
Ah. Hello.
Good afternoon, sir. Might I be of assistance?
EDWARD STOPS BY THE DOCTOR.
You’re a.. footman?
A waiter, sir.
Excellent. And, forgive me - are those newspapers you’re carrying...?
The evening papers, sir. Delivered a little later than usual a quarter to four - but still in time for tea in the drawing room.
Of course! Tea in the drawing room. May I?
Please.
THE DOCTOR TAKES A PAPER FROM THE TOP OF EDWARD'S PILE.
Thank you, ah...?
Edward, sir.
Thank you, Edward.
You’re most welcome, sir.
EDWARD STARTS TO LEAVE.
Oh, and Edward?
Yes, sir?
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 18
The drawing room is...?
This way, sir. The end of the gallery, turn left, then one floor down.
Thank you. I’1ll be along presently.
Very good, sir.
EDWARD WALKS ON.
Hmm. Now let’s see.
HE UNFOLDS THE PAPER.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 19
8. INT. TARDIS, CONTROL ROOM
ADRIC POPS HIS HEAD BACK INSIDE THE TARDIS.
Hello. We’re not dead.
Adric! Don’t joke about things like that.
Everything seems safe enough. Breathable air and everything.
So where are we?
The Doctor says it looks like Earth. Although it might be the wrong date.
That’d be right. We’re probably in the middle of a seventeenth- century plague again.
So are you not going to come out? It’s better than sitting in the dark.
Adric’s probably right, Tegan.
Oh... all right! Seeing as the TARDIS isn’t going anywhere!
Come on then.
NYSSA AND ADRIC FOLLOW ADRIC OUT OF THE TARDIS.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 20
9. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, GALLERY
ADRIC, TEGAN AND NYSSA EMERGE. THE DOCTOR IS READING THE NEWSPAPER.
Well. Not even the Club Class Lounge at Heathrow looked this fancy!
Doctor? What’s that?
It’s called a newspaper. Helpful chap called Edward gave it to me.
(READING) ‘The Pall Mall Gazette’? That’s not a modern newspaper. Is it?
Well... Modern is a relative concept, Tegan...
Are we in the nineteen-eighties, Doctor?
Ah... No. This appears to indicate... that we’re in eighteen-sixty- four.
A bit early to catch any flights, then!
But what could have affected the TARDIS...?
I don’t know... I can’t spot anything.
FOOTSTEPS - WAKEFIELD APPROACHING.
Doctor. Someone’s coming.
Ah.
WAKEFIELD (OFF) Hello, sir. I haven’t quite got my bearings yet.
No? Well, nor have we.
WAKEFIELD STOPS BY THEM.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 21
Do you know if I’m heading the right way for the drawing room?
Yes. It’s the end of the gallery, turn left, then one floor down.
(SOFT) How do you know that?!
I’m the Doctor, by the way. This is Adric, Tegan and Nyssa.
Granville Wakefield, at your service. Are you established Club members?
Club members? No, we’re -
- new. Very new.
Capital! Then we are in the same boat! Shall we go together?
Delighted. As long as we.. I mean, we aren’t conventionally attired for afternoon tea.
Nonsense. You all look perfectly respectable.
What? Even pajama boy there?
Hey!
(UNSURE) Well, if you think we will pass muster...
Of course! Lead on. I’m looking forward to some refreshment, I don’t mind telling you...!
THEY ALL START TO MOVE OFF DOWN THE CORRIDOR.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 22
10. INT. AUGUSTUS HOUSE, DRAWING ROOM
A CLOCK TICKS. AUGUSTUS AND MARJORIE SIT OPPOSITE ONE ANOTHER. AUGUSTUS POURS TEA.
There we are, Miss Stonegood.
Thank you, Mr Augustus.
MARJORIE SIPS FROM HER CHINA TEACUP.
Pray continue. The new Underground Railway...?
My father was one of the principal engineers. In charge of tunnelling.
Such an endeavour! A wonder of our modern age! But you were saying...?
He has disappeared. He has vanished! And I believe it must be connected to the Contingency Club!
AUGUSTUS PUTS HIS TEA DOWN.
(VERY INTERESTED) The Club? Go on.
A representative came to consult my father. I was away at the time.. enduring the last term of boarding school. But I have the housekeeper’s account.
And?
My father visited the Club. He never returned home!
A mystery indeed...
I have no other guardian, sir. My mother died in childbirth. My father is everything to me! Please. You must help me discover the truth.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 23
11. INT. THE CONTINGENCY CLUB, DRAWING ROOM
A REFINED HUBBUB OF CONVIVIAL GENTLEMANLY CHATTER. THE DOCTOR,
TEGAN, NYSSA, ADRIC AND WAKEFIELD ENTER.
I suppose this is the drawing room.
Big, isn't at?
Magnificent! Ah, Edward.
EDWARD STEPS OVER.
EDWARD 1 Yes, sir?
Edward. Hello again.
We'll sit over there. Send a waiter over would you?
EDWARD 1 Of course, sir. Someone will be with you
THE PARTY MOVES TO THEIR SEATS.
(SOFTLY) Nyssa...
Yes?
Everyone’s ignoring us.
That’s a bad thing?
for refreshments,
directly.
Well. We don’t readily fit into a nineteenth century
gentlemen’s club.
But Mr Wakefield said -
- Yes. Which is also puzzling...
THEY STOP.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 24
Do take a seat, gentlemen.
And ladies?
Eh?
THEY SIT. IMMEDIATELY AN EDWARD APPEARS.
EDWARD 2 Might I offer some refreshments?
Ah, Edward!
Flip. That was quick.
I thought he was sending someone else?
Brandy please, Edward, for myself. Anyone else?
(TO DOCTOR) What’s ‘brandy’, Doctor?
(TO ADRIC) It’s not a good idea, Adric. (TO EDWARD) We’re for the moment, thank you.
EDWARD 2 Very good, sir.
HE WALKS OFF, BUT IMMEDIATELY - FROM ANOTHER DIRECTION.
EDWARD 3 Newspaper, sir?
Ah, thank you, Edward.
HE TAKES A PAPER.
What the - ? He just left...!
There are two of them?
Twins...?
fine
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 25
EDWARD 3 Do call if you require anything else, sir.
HE WALKS OFF, BUT IMMEDIATELY, FROM THE FIRST DIRECTION -
EDWARD 2 Your brandy, sir.
HE PUTS DOWN A GLASS, POURS FROM A DECANTER.
This is too strange.
WAKEFIELD SHAKES OUT HIS NEWSPAPER.
Thank you, Edward.
EDWARD 2 Sir.
EDWARD 2 LEAVES ONCE MORE.
(SIPS) Ahhh! This is the life, eh? What a Club is all about! Pleasant company. An escape from the domestic sphere, yet all the comforts a gentleman could want!
Or lady.
Eh?
All the comforts a gentleman - or a lady - could want.
Oh, no. No, no. Club rules are quite firm on that.
I’m sorry?
The Club does not permit women to enter. Naturally.
What...?
I know of one establishment that now opens its gates to the fairer sex - once a week on a Wednesday evening, I believe... But I’m pleased to say the Contingency has not followed suit!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 26
But... what about me and Nyssa?
(OBLIVIOUS) No, no. In my opinion, their presence on that one day, would simply unsettle me for the other six! (LAUGHS)
But Nyssa and I! We’re women!
Eh? Oh... (LAUGHS) Very good, sir! You are a jester, I see!
Doctor? What’s going on?!
Something very strange. I want to speak to Edward again. Where did he go? (CALLS) Edward!
IMMEDIATELY THREE EDWARDS STEP IN, FROM DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS, OVERLAPPING AS THEY SPEAK.
EDWARD 1 Yes, sir?
EDWARD 2 Might I be of assistance?
EDWARD 3 Is there something you require?
Flaming Nora! Three of them!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 27
12. INT. AUGUSTUS HOUSE, STUDY
You have gone to the police about this matter, Miss Stonegood?
They dismissed me as a girl who reads too many gothic novels.
And I dare say they are reluctant to cause trouble within Clubland...
Oh, yes! St James and Pall Mall must be protected from unsavoury accusations at all costs!
Well. It’s naturally unthinkable that a club member should behave dishonourably.
Unthinkable?
My dear girl, all the regulations of London’s clubs boil down to one rule: that a member should behave like a gentleman.
Then where is my father, Mr Augustus? He would not leave me without word! You know the clubs. You write the society news. Will you not make enquiries for me?
But I am not permitted to even enter the Contingency Club, Miss Stonegood.
What? But I.. I thought you were a Club man through and through!
Membership of that particular institution eludes me. And to be frank... my chances would not be helped by throwing out accusations!
(ANGRY) Then you are as helpful as the police. And I must consider more desperate measures. Thank you for your time, sir.
MARJORIE PUTS DOWN HER TEA, STANDS TO LEAVE.
Please, Miss Stonegood. Wait.
SHE PAUSES.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 28
AUGUSTUS (CONT ’D) What do you mean by ‘desperate measures’?
It is better you do not know, sir. You would not wish to be implicated in anything ‘dishonourable’. Good day.
SHE EXITS.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 29
13. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, DRAWING ROOM
THE GENIAL HUBBUB CONTINUES. THE EDWARDS SPEAK FROM DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS.
EDWARD 1 Is there anything you require, sir?
EDWARD 2 Some refreshments?
EDWARD 3 We are here to assist.
Three servants...
Absolutely identical...
Triplets?
Ah... Edward?
(FROM ALL DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS) Yes?
You’re all called Edward?
Yes.
(TO EDWARD 2) You. You brought, Mr Wakefield his brandy.
EDWARD 2 Yes, sir.
(TO EDWARD 1) And you brought over a newspaper.
EDWARD 3 No, sir. That was me. You must be confusing me with my brother.
Not hard under the circumstances...!
EDWARD 3 I am Edward the fourth.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL)
The fourth?
Yes, I see. (TO EDWARD 2) While you are...?
EDWARD 2 Edward the eighth, sir.
Of course.
How many are there?
(TO EDWARD 1) And you... ah... Edward?
EDWARD 1 Edward the Twenty Third, sir.
I had to ask...
Most strange.
You think?
Edward, can you tell me who’s in charge here?
Page
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 31
14. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, QUEEN’S CHAMBERS
A SOFT BACKGROUND TICKING AND PUFFING. ALL THE INSTRUMENTS IN THE QUEEN’S CHAMBERS RUN BY CLOCKWORK OR STEAM POWER. PEABODY AND THE RED QUEEN PLAY CHESS.
Your move, my Queen.
Pawn to Queen’s Bishop four.
THEY MOVE PIECES, UNDER -
Hmm... Pawn to King’s Knight three.
Bishop takes pawn.
My Queen! An excellent move!
Do not grovel, Peabody. Any game is joyless unless played at full pelt, between two earnest rivals.
Of course, my Queen. But... as you have just now learnt the rules...
It will be the more embarrassing for you, when you lose! Your move.
Knight to Queen’s Bishop three.
Did you successfully recruit the scientist - Wakefield?
Of course, my Queen. He joined the Club this afternoon. I believe he is in the drawing room.
Good. He will be useful. The pieces are nearly in place. My plan reaches its end game.
Yes, my Queen.
THE DOOR TO THE CHAMBERS GRINDS OPENS — THANKS TO A MECHANISM OF CLOCKWORK AND STEAM. EDWARD ENTERS.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 32
Do forgive the intrusion, Mr Peabody.
What is it, Edward?
Strangers, sir.
Strangers?
They appeared in the Club. Our instructions were to inform you, should this ever happen.
Strangers? Who are they, Peabody?
I do not know, my Queen!
They might be spies! How did they get in?
I have no idea. It’s impossible, my Queen!
Evidently not! They must be got rid of. At once!
Yes, my Queen! At once. Come, Edward!
PEABODY RISES, AND EXITS WITH EDWARD.
(CALLS) Nothing must interfere with the game, Peabody! Nothing!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 33
15. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, DRAWING ROOM
In charge, sir? Mr Peabody is Club Chairman.
Peabody, eh? I’d very much like to meet him.
Have you got an explanation for all this, Doctor?
Not yet, Tegan.
AT THE DOOR, MORE EDWARDS ENTER THE DRAWING ROOM.
Doctor - over there, at the door. More of them!
Yes. A whole... what is the collective noun for Edwards?
They seem to be looking for something.
Ah. It might be time for us to leave.
HE STANDS.
Leave? Why?
Oh, you get a sense for these things.
PEABODY (OFF) They’re over there! Seize them, Edwards!
PEABODY AND THE EDWARDS CROSS THE ROOM.
Sometimes it’s a curse to be right. Come on!
TEGAN, NYSSA AND ADRIC STAND.
PEABODY (OFF) You Edwards there —- hold them!
THE THREE EDWARDS BY THE DOCTOR GRAB TEGAN, NYSSA AND ADRIC.
Hey! (STRUGGLING) Get off!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 34
EDWARD 1 Apologies, sir.
(STRUGGLING) Let go!
EDWARD 2 I do hope this is not uncomfortable.
(STRUGGLING) Stop it!
PEABODY ARRIVES.
Hold them! (TO DOCTOR) You. How did you get in? You are not Club members!
Why not let my companions go? Then we can talk.
I think not.
Then you leave me no choice. (SUDDENLY SHOUTS TO THE ROOM) Gentlemen! Help us! Kidnap! Help!

his

#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 95

47. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, QUEEN’S CHAMBERS
STATIC CRACKLES FROM A HYPERSPACE COM-LINK.
(ANGRY) Of course I have held to the agreed rules, brother!
KNAVE (D) I do not know whether to believe you.
Why would I break them? When I am so close to victory?
KNAVE (D) I know you, sister. You would do anything to win.
No! I have only used Earth materials. I have only worked with available technologies. Look at my chambers here! Primitive mechanisms. Clockwork! Steam power! I have not even disguised my appearance!
KNAVE (D)
But I detected an incoming energy pattern. Something far beyond Terran technology. There for but a nanosecond - but detected nonetheless. I have caught you out, sister!
An incoming energy pattern. Just like this com-link, brother. You know the failsafes in place had it been otherwise — had it been generated by me.
KNAVE (D) Mmm... But do you know what it was?
(BEAT) No. A travel capsule of some kind appeared within the Club. A blue box.
KNAVE (D) Yet you claim to have stayed within the rules?!

MARJORIE: A what?
DOCTOR: A vehicle for travelling to the stars. This is its flight deck. The Club has been built around it.
MARJORIE: You’re joking. This is the stuff of fiction!
ADRIC: If the Club’s built around it, how can it fly?
DOCTOR: It isn’t meant to. Not at present anyway.
DOCTOR: THE DOCTOR STRIDES OVER TO A BANK OF INSTRUMENTS.
MARJORIE: What do you mean?
DOCTOR: It’s dormant. These screens here... Look. Blank.
DOCTOR: HE FLICKS A FEW SWITCHES.
DOCTOR: DOCTOR (CONT’D) No power. None of the flight systems booted up. It’s dead. (BEAT.) Just like the TARDTG...
MARJORIE: But there are instruments working in here. You can hear them!
MARJORIE: THE DOCTOR WALKS ROUND.
DOCTOR: These devices are clockwork. Perpetual motion machines. Steam powered! Look at this...!
DOCTOR: THE DOCTOR WALKS OVER TO SOMETHING.
DOCTOR: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 118
DOCTOR: A mechanical calculating device. A computer, in effect.
ADRIC: That’s a computer? You might as well use an abacus!
DOCTOR: But the thinking behind all this is more advanced than anything from eighteen-sixty-four. Look there!
DOCTOR: ANOTHER DEVICE PUFFS SOFTLY AWAY.
ADRIC: A clock.
DOCTOR: A steam-powered clock. Ingenious.
DOCTOR: MARJORIE (OFF) Whoever lives here, they like games.
DOCTOR: What?
DOCTOR: MARJORIE (OFF) Look in this cabinet.
DOCTOR: THE DOCTOR AND ADRIC WALK OVER.
DOCTOR: MARJORIE(CONT’D) Chess. Draughts. Nine man’s morris. Backgammon... Packs of cards.
DOCTOR: A football... A croquet mallet.
MARJORIE: Golf clubs. Tennis racquets.
ADRIC: What are all these things?
MARJORIE: You play games with them.
ADRIC: Games ?
DOCTOR: (EXCITED) Ah!
DOCTOR: THE DOCTOR LIFTS SOMETHING OUT OF THE CABINET.
MARJORIE: A cricket bat.
MARJORIE: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 119
MARJORIE: THE DOCTOR TAKES A STANCE. TRIES A FEW STROKES.
MARJORIE: DOCTOR (CONT’D) Good weight... Nice balance... Is there a cricket ball too, Adric?
ADRIC: Yes... (PICKING UP A BALL) But Doctor - without wanting to sound like Tegan, shouldn’t you focus on the matter in hand?
DOCTOR: You’re probably right.
MARJORIE: But what is the matter in hand? What does all this mean?!
MARJORIE: THE QUEEN APPEARS AT A DOORWAY.
MARJORIE: QUEEN (OFF) It means I have intruders in my chambers!
MARJORIE: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 120
NYSSA: (SOFTLY) So who is this ‘Red Queen’, Tegan?
TEGAN: (SOFTLY) I only heard a bit about her in the carriage on the way here. According to Augustus — she’s the force behind the whole Club.
NYSSA: What?
TEGAN: Yes. Ironic, isn’t it? A gentlemen’s club that doesn’t admit women, ruled by a Queen.
TEGAN: FOOTSTEPS - A DOZEN EDWARDS ENTER THE HALL.
AUGUSTUS: Ah, excellent. My Edwards.
EDWARDS: Mr Peabody. / Sir / etc.
PEABODY: Well, Augustus? What shall I tell them to do?
AUGUSTUS: It is so very tedious, Mr Peabody, you passing on my instructions all the time.
PEABODY: They will obey only my commands, or my Queen’s.
AUGUSTUS: So command this group to obey me.
PEABODY: I... What?
PEABODY: AUGUSTUS RAISES HIS GUN AND COCKS IT.
AUGUSTUS: Now, if you please, Mr Peabody.
PEABODY: (BEAT, DESPAIRING) Edwards?
EDWARDS: Mr Peabody, sir? / Sir? / Mr Peabody? / etc.
PEABODY: This is Mr George Augustus. For the present, you are to obey
PEABODY: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 121
PEABODY: whatever commands he gives you. Do you understand?
EDWARDS: Yes, Mr Peabody.
EDWARDS: EDWARD 1 How may we assist you, Mr Augustus?
AUGUSTUS: I’m so glad you asked, Edward. (POINTING) You and you - take hold of Miss Jovanka and Miss Ovtraken here.
AUGUSTUS: EDWARD 1 & 2 Yes, sir.
AUGUSTUS: THEY GRAB HOLD OF NYSSA AND TEGAN.
TEGAN: (STRUGGLING) Hey! Get off!
TEGAN: EDWARD 1 I do apologise, miss.
NYSSA: Oh, not again...!
AUGUSTUS: The rest of you. Fetch explosives from the tunnels. Bring them to the Club cellar. Do you understand?
EDWARDS: Yes, Mr Augustus.
EDWARDS: THE OTHER EDWARDS EXIT.
AUGUSTUS: Excellent! (LAUGHS) Now, you two. Take Miss Jovanka and Miss Ovtraken to the cellar.
TEGAN: What? Why?
AUGUSTUS: I said I would find somewhere safe for you, Miss Jovanka.
NYSSA: But you’re having explosives taken to the cellar!
AUGUSTUS: Indeed. I should explain... I meant I would put you somewhere safe for me. Edwards, take them!
AUGUSTUS: EDWARD 1 & 2 Yes, Mr Augustus. / Yes, sir.
AUGUSTUS: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 122
AUGUSTUS: THE EDWARDS DRAG NYSSA AND TEGAN OFF - AS THEY PROTEST.
AUGUSTUS: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 123
DOCTOR: The Red Queen, I presume?
QUEEN: Some know me by that name.
MARJORIE: (SHOCKED) I can see why! (QUIETLY) Doctor, is that stage make- up or is her skin really -
DOCTOR: (QUIETLY) - Red? All natural, I assure you.
ADRIC: (QUIETLY) She’s not human, obviously?
DOCTOR: (QUIETLY) Quite. Please, Marjorie — don’t stare.
MARJORIE: (QUIETLY) Why not?
DOCTOR: (QUIETLY) Well, it’s rude.
QUEEN: As is neglecting to name yourselves!
DOCTOR: Of course. Forgive me. I’m the Doctor. This is Adric. And that’s Marjorie. We’ve been admiring your chambers.
QUEEN: I presume that you are the strangers who invaded my Club. Ina mysterious blue box?
DOCTOR: That was quite accidental, I assure you. (PATTING THE CRICKET BAT) This is a lovely bat, by the way. Could do with a touch of linseed oil...
QUEEN: You play the fool, Doctor. But I do not believe that you are one.
DOCTOR: That’s a very generous assessment.
QUEEN: You are here to sabotage the game. Are you not?
QUEEN: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 124
DOCTOR: Game?
QUEEN: Don’t feign ignorance! Did my brother send you?
ADRIC: The Doctor’s told you. We arrived here by accident.
QUEEN: I do not believe you.
ADRIC: It’s the truth!
QUEEN: No matter. You are too late. The end game is in motion.
DOCTOR: End game? You mean the explosives?
QUEEN: (BEAT) What do you know of the explosives?
DOCTOR: Not as much as I’d like. But do tell. I’m always interested in the plans of power-crazed despots.
DOCTOR: THE QUEEN WALKS TO THE DISPLAY CABINET.
ADRIC: (WHISPERED) Doctor, we should get out of here!
DOCTOR: (WHISPERED) We need to find out what this ‘game’ is.
QUEEN: The people of this nation are fond of sports, are they not? Team games. Racquet games. Board games, card games. Even hunting. This, for example...
QUEEN: LIFTS SOMETHING OUT OF THE CABINET.
QUEEN: QUEEN (CONT’D) . is a particularly fine example of a hunting rifle.
QUEEN: SHE WORKS THE RIFLE’S BOLT.
DOCTOR: Indeed.
QUEEN: Perhaps you should have picked this up, Doctor. Rather than the cricket bat?
QUEEN: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 125
DOCTOR: I’d choose the sound of leather on willow over a gunshot any
DOCTOR: day.
QUEEN: Against that wall, please. All of you. Now.
QUEEN: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 126
QUEEN: THE EDWARDS DRAG TEGAN AND NYSSA DOWN THE CELLAR STEPS.
TEGAN: Ow! My shin!
TEGAN: AUGUSTUS AND PEABODY ENTER BEHIND.
AUGUSTUS: Stop there, Edwards.
AUGUSTUS: THE EDWARDS STOP.
AUGUSTUS: AUGUSTUS (CONT'D) Peabody, fetch that rope, would you?
PEABODY: (UNHAPPY) If I must.
PEABODY: HE GETS IT.
AUGUSTUS: Excellent. Give it to the Edwards. They will tie up Miss Jovanka and Miss Ovtraken.
AUGUSTUS: EDWARD 1 & 2 Yes, Mr Augustus.
AUGUSTUS: THE EDWARDS FORCE TEGAN AND NYSSA TO SIT AND TIE THEM.
NYSSA: (STRUGGLING) You don’t have to do this!
NYSSA: EDWARD 1 Would you mind terribly not wriggling, Miss?
TEGAN: I would, actually!
TEGAN: THEY’RE TIED.
AUGUSTUS: Good. Safe and sound.
TEGAN: When I get out of these ropes...!
TEGAN: FOOTSTEPS - A LARGE GROUP OF EDWARDS APPROACH.
AUGUSTUS: Ah! And here are the others!
AUGUSTUS: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 127
AUGUSTUS: EDWARD 3 We have the explosives, sir.
AUGUSTUS: Excellent! Set them just there. Beside Miss Jovanka and Miss Ovtraken.
TEGAN: What?!
EDWARDS: Yes, sir.
EDWARDS: THE EDWARDS SET DOWN CRATES OF EXPLOSIVES.
NYSSA: What are you doing?
AUGUSTUS: (TO EDWARDS) Make sure the fuse wires are connected. Then pass me the spool of wire and a detonator.
TEGAN: Are you mad?
TEGAN: EDWARD 3 The spool and detonator, sir.
TEGAN: GIVES THE DRUM OF FUSE WIRE TO AUGUSTUS.
AUGUSTUS: Thank you.
NYSSA: You can’t leave us right beside these explosives!
NYSSA: AUGUSTUS BEGINS TO LEAVE, UNSPOOLING THE FUSE WIRE.
AUGUSTUS: Don’t distract me, my dear. This fuse wire has to stretch all the way up through the Club. I’m sure you don’t want me to snag it on anything and accidentally set this lot off. Farewell.
AUGUSTUS: AUGUSTUS STARTS TO EXIT.
TEGAN: Augustus! No! Come back here! Don’t leave us!
TEGAN: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 128
QUEEN: Back against the wall, I said!
MARJORIE: Doctor?
DOCTOR: It’s all right, Marjorie. Do as she says.
DOCTOR: THE DOCTOR, MARJORIE AND ADRIC BACK AGAINST THE WALL.
ADRIC: (QUIETLY) I told you we should have got out!
QUEEN: All the cards are in my hand, Doctor.
DOCTOR: So it seems.
QUEEN: (SMILING) You admit that you cannot stop me?
DOCTOR: I don’t even know what the explosives you’ve got stored downstairs are for.
QUEEN: (LAUGHS) Allow me to explain. They are for Parliament. For Trafalgar Square. For Covent Garden. At this moment, they are being packed beneath half the prominent sites of this capital!
MARJORIE: You mean to blow up London?! You can’t!
QUEEN: I won't.
ADRIC: You... won’t?
QUEEN: (LAUGHS) It is but a bargaining chip.
DOCTOR: Hundreds of innocent lives put at risk — as a ‘bargaining chip’?
QUEEN: A strong one, no?
QUEEN: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 129
DOCTOR: And whom exactly are you bargaining with?
QUEEN: I have remained here, Doctor, hidden away in my chambers until my plans were ready. But barely half a mile away another Queen sits - in Buckingham Palace.
MARJORIE: Queen Victoria...?
QUEEN: And now, at last, it is time for the Red Queen to take the White! The gentlemen of my Club all stand ready to ease my transition to power. They will serve me, even unto death! Victoria’s Empire will be mine. And then all the empires this planet affords!
DOCTOR: The same old story! How tiresomely predictable, my Queen.
QUEEN: You think so?
DOCTOR: Oh, I’ve seen it all before. Again and again. A petty despot with a desire to take over the world, the galaxy, the universe! You’re nothing special. Doing all this because of an insatiable lust for power! A thirst for conquest! A desire to dominate!
QUEEN: You are wrong, Doctor!
DOCTOR: Am I?
QUEEN: I’m doing it for a bet, Doctor.
DOCTOR: (UTTER SURPRISE) A what?!
QUEEN: (SIMPLY) A bet. A wager with my brother.
DOCTOR: A bet?
QUEEN: Now all the pieces are in place on the board. Queen Victoria will kneel before me. She will hand me her crown. And victory, Doctor... will be mine!!
QUEEN: END OF PART THREE
QUEEN: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 130

elements.text: PART FOUR

Oh, I’ve seen it all before. Again and again. A petty despot with a desire to take over the world, the galaxy, the universe! You’re nothing special. Doing all this because of an insatiable lust for power! A thirst for conquest! A desire to dominate!
You are wrong, Doctor!
Am I?
I’m doing it for a bet, Doctor.
(UTTER SURPRISE) A what?!
(SIMPLY) A bet. A wager with my brother.
A bet?
Now all the pieces are in place on the board. Queen Victoria will kneel before me. She will hand me her crown. And victory, Doctor... will be mine!!
63. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, QUEEN’S CHAMBERS [CONTINUED]
(TAKING IT IN) A bet...
My family is known as The Contingency. A race of game players. We have played for several worlds in our time.
And the Earth is just another one?
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 131
Oh, but a very special one. My brother wagered I could not take it without superior technology. I disagreed. I said cunning and tactics alone could sway any game.
No advanced technology? But the devices in here... the explosives?
The Edwards!
I have used only materials that Earth provides. Built only with its current technologies.
But using knowledge far in advance of the nineteenth century!
As the rules allow. Soon, at last, Victoria will hand her crown to me. Or see her people destroyed...
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 132
64. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, CELLAR
TEGAN STRAINS AT HER BONDS.
Tegan? Are the ropes loosening?
No! Ow!
SHE STOPS STRUGGLING.
Does Augustus really plan on blowing up the Club?
With him inside it? He doesn’t seem insane.
Mmm.
But who knows? Club members who can’t see what’s in front of them. Cloned servants. A journalist who turns out to be spying for some alien! Everything’s been insane since we landed in this madhouse!
Those Edwards can tie a good knot anyway. Poor creatures.
‘Poor’?
They’ve been bred for a purpose, Tegan. Completely subservient. They’re victims.
So will we be if we don't get free of these knots.
SHE STARTS STRUGGLING AGAIN.
TEGAN (CONT’D) Ow!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 133
65. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, QUEEN’S CHAMBERS
You’re quite the problem gambler, my Queen. It’s called ludomania. Gambling addiction. A destructive habit.
You try to goad me, Doctor.
I presume your brother demanded failsafes - to detect any use of advanced technology?
He insisted. Use of such technology would immediately revive my ship. Trigger an immediate jump into hyperspace.
So now I know why the TARDIS shut down! Good to be cautious about triggering hyperspace jumps.
You can’t really believe Queen Victoria will hand you her throne.
When her capital and her people are threatened with destruction?
(WHISPER) Adric, do you still have that cricket ball?
(WHISPER) Yes.
What about my father?
Who?
(WHISPER) I want you to throw it at me - when I say.
(WHISPER) What?
(WHISPER) I’ve still got the bat...
William Stonegood.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 134
Stonegood... The engineer. Forgive me, there are so many prominent men within my Club. Yes. His tunnelling expertise proved most useful. He remains here as our guest.
He’s here?
Well, this has been most enlightening, my Queen! But we must dash now.
THE DOCTOR WALKS FORWARD.
Still playing the fool, Doctor? Stop there.
SHE WORKS THE BOLT ON HER RIFLE.
QUEEN (CONT’D) Stop. Or I fire!
THE DOCTOR STOPS.
Probably a hook shot from this angle.
What?
You're familiar with cricketing terminology? I’m aiming for square leg.
Aiming?
Yes. (SHOUTS) The ball, Adric! Now!
Here!
ADRIC TOSSES THE BALL. THE DOCTOR HOOKS IT ACROSS THE CHAMBER — STRAIGHT INTO THE STEAM CLOCK, DAMAGING IT. STEAM HISSES OUT.
What have you done?!
Hit that steam-powered clock of yours!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 135
To what purpose-?! (REALISATION) You think clouds of vapour will put me off my aim! Well — you are wrong!
SHE RAISES THE RIFLE.
Doctor, look out!
A GUNSHOT. THE DOCTOR DIVES.
Doctor?!
I’m fine!
Very wrong!
SHE RELOADS HER RIFLE.
Adric, Marjorie! Before she can reload! Let’s go!
I can’t see! Where are you?
Follow my voice!
MARJORIE GROPES OVER TO THE DOCTOR.
DOCTOR (CONT’D) This way... That’s it... Got you!
HE GRABS MARJORIE’S HAND.
You will not leave!
SHE RAISES HER RIFLE, FIRES ANOTHER SHOT!
She’s firing blindly! Adric?!
Over here. But I can’t see either!
The door control...!
SHE GROPES FOR A LEVER. THE DOOR’S CLOCKWORK GRINDS INTO ACTION.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 136
The door’s closing! This way, Marjorie! Adric, come on!
THE DOCTOR GUIDES MARJORIE TO THE EXIT.
Wait...!
ADRIC FOLLOWS, BUT COLLIDES WITH SOMETHING. HE FALLS.
ADRIC (CONT’D) Ooof! Doctor, wait—!
THE DOOR CLOSES — THUNK!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 137
66. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, GALLERY, CONTINUOUS
Adric!
He didn’t make it! He’s still in there!
We have to get the door open again!
HE PULLS THE PICTURE RAIL. IT CLICKS, BUT NOTHING HAPPENS.
Doctor?
It’s not opening! The Queen’s overridden it!
Then what else we can do?
THE DOCTOR FEELS HIS POCKETS.
(FRUSTRATED) Until very recently, I had a sonic screwdriver. Now all I’ve got is...
THE DOCTOR PULLS OUT TEGAN’S WALKMAN.
DOCTOR (CONT’D) . a nineteen-eighties personal cassette player...!
A what?
Something I confiscated from Tegan, never mind.
HE SHOVES IT BACK IN HIS POCKET.
DOCTOR (CONT’D) Perhaps we can force our way in... But we’ll need help! Come on!
THE DOCTOR AND MARJORIE RUN OFF.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 138
67. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, QUEEN’S CHAMBERS
THE STEAM HISSING INTO THE CHAMBERS EASES.
Your friends have gone, Adric. I have sealed the door. And the steam begins to clear.
SHE WALKS FORWARD.
At least they got away...
No matter. You are my hostage. And the odds will turn in my favour once more.
The odds! You speak as if you care about probability - about chance! I know the mathematics behind those concepts. But you dislike pure chance as much as anybody I’ve ever met.
A mathematician? Perhaps you are worthy to join my Club?
No, thank you.
Chance can provide a certain spice within a game, Adric. But I much prefer to have bargaining chips in hand...
So now I’m a bargaining chip too? Like the people of London. The Doctor will stop you, you know.
I think not. My servant Peabody will be here shortly — ready to carry my ultimatum to the Palace. And as he goes, he can instruct the Edwards to hunt down your troublesome Doctor!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 139
68. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, DRAWING ROOM
CHATTER. DRINKS TAKEN. PAPERS RUSTLED. THE DOCTOR AND MARJORIE RUN IN.
Excellent! Lots of Club members!
But their perceptions... You said they were altered.
Perhaps we can cut through the conditioning. We must try!
(GASPS) Doctor!
What is it?
My father!
SHE RUNS ACROSS THE ROOM.
MARJORIE (CONT’D) (CALLING) Father!
DOCTOR (OFF) (FOLLOWING) Marjorie, wait! He might not be able to -
SHE REACHES HIM.
- Father!
(LOOKING UP) Hmm? Ah. Good afternoon, sir.
Father...?
Forgive me. Have we met?
It’s me, Father. Marjorie!
I’m afraid you have me at a disadvantage...
(SOBS) Oh... Father...
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 140
THE DOCTOR GENTLY PULLS HER BACK.
Marjorie... your father’s under a very powerful influence.
Then we must free him!
We will. But our first priority is Adric - and the Queen.
How can anyone here help? If they can’t even recognise their own children!
You might have a point... (SPOTS SOMETHING) Wait a moment...!
What is it?
Over there..! It’s Mr Augustus! He must have found a way in! Wait here.
HE RUNS BACK TO THE DOOR.
DOCTOR (CONT’D) (CALLING) Mr Augustus!
AUGUSTUS (OFF) Doctor...?
You found a way in!
Ah... Yes! With a little help.
Help? Even better! Whose help?
(CALLS) Mr Peabody?
PEABODY ENTERS.
(UNHAPPY) Yes?
(SURPRISED) Peabody...?
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 141
Ah, of course. You have met before. But Mr Peabody is proving much more amenable now than when he so rudely ejected you.
Is he? Why?
Well, I confess this revolver of mine has helped. (LIFTS GUN)
Well done, Mr Augustus! Smaller than the Red Queen’s, but serviceable nonetheless.
(INTERESTED) You have seen the Queen?
Yes.
Our next port of call! Lead on!
Where’s Tegan? And Nyssa?
Tied up at present.
Doing what?
He means literally tied up. In the cellar. Surrounded by explosives.
What?
Mr Peabody, please only speak when I request you to. Now come, Doctor. I have several Edwards who follow my commands. But I’d prefer not to restrain you.
(BEAT) I suppose I have no choice.
Eminently sensible. Shall we?
AUGUSTUS, THE DOCTOR, AND PEABODY EXIT. MARJORIE WALKS FORWARD.
(TO SELF) Nyssa’s in the cellar...?
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 142
69. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, CELLAR
(STRUGGLING) Oh, this is useless!
We can’t give up, Tegan!
But we can’t get free either!
FOOTSTEPS OFF - MARJORIE RUSHING DOWN THE STAIRS.
Shh. Someone’s coming...!
MARJORIE (OFF) Hello...? Nyssa?
Marjorie..! Over here!
SHE RUSHES OVER.
Nyssa! Goodness. Explosives!
Yes, all around us — we don’t need reminding!
Marjorie, this is Tegan. Can you get us free?
T’1l try...
MARJORIE KNEELS AND STARTS ON THE ROPES.
So you got into the Club?
Yes. And we found the Red Queen! She’s got Adric prisoner!
What?
But the Doctor and I escaped. Then I found my father. Nyssa — he didn’t even recognise me.
Oh, Marjorie...
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 143
And then Mr Augustus turned up! He’s -
- Oh, we know exactly what he is.
I ducked out of sight. But he took the Doctor. (FINISHES ROPES) There! Done it!
NYSSA AND TEGAN WRIGGLE FREE.
(STRETCHING) Does that feel good!
Thank you, Marjorie.
So should we try and rescue the Doctor?
We should do something about these explosives first!
SHE EXAMINES THEM.
(NERVOUS) Tegan, please be careful.
It’s fine. They look stable enough... So long as Augustus doesn’t detonate them, I mean! The blasting caps are what set them off.
Blasting caps?
Yes. These things at the ends - connected to the fuse wire.
How do you know?
I had some cousins who did blast mining, back in Australia.
The penal colony?
Don’t insult my country. Not while I’m holding explosives. Come on. If we remove the blasting caps... nothing should go boom!
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 144
70. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, GALLERY
THE DOCTOR, AUGUSTUS AND PEABODY ARRIVE BY THE QUEEN’S CHAMBERS - AUGUSTUS UNSPOOLING FUSE WIRE.
This is it, Augustus. The entrance to my Queen’s chambers.
And what’s this blue box? (READING) ‘Police’?
You’1l need to ask the Doctor.
Indeed...? (IMPATIENT) Later then. Open the door.
You can’t. She’s sealed it from the inside.
Then how do we get in?
PEABODY KNOCKS THE WALL.
My Queen? It is I - Peabody!
BEAT.
Well, that was ineffect-
THE DOOR GRINDS INTO ACTION. AUGUSTUS (CONT’D) At last! You first, Peabody.
of this detonator... Move!
THEY ENTER.
I.. cannot gain access!
Then you, Doctor. I must take care
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 145
71. INT. CONTINGENCY CLUB, QUEEN’S CHAMBERS, CONTINUOUS
PEABODY AND THE DOCTOR WALK IN.
(CAUTIOUS) My Queen...?
Peabody.
Doctor!
Adric! Are you all right?
I am sorry, my Queen...! He forced me to bring him!
Who? The Doctor?
AUGUSTUS STEPS FORWARD.
I believe he means me, my Queen.
Who are you?
He calls himself George Augustus. At a rough guess, I'd say he’s an agent of your brother’s - here to sabotage your game.
(OUTRAGED) What...?
Listen to me! As we speak, a large pile of explosives rests in the cellar of your Club. I hold the detonator here. (LIFTS IT)
No...
We're probably safe from any blast - here in your chambers.
But the rest of the Club won’t be.
Precisely. And without your Club - without its members... your plans to take the Empire will lie in ruins, my Queen.
#222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 146
This... is a foul! Unsportsmanlike! Not fair play!
‘Fair play’? (LAUGHS) This is a bet where the winner takes
You'd really wipe out the members of the Club?
And Tegan and Nyssa.
Acceptable losses.
You’re as monstrous as her.
This is a bluff! Peabody?
The explosives are in the cellar, my Queen. I am sorry.
You have betrayed me!
No, my Queen! Augustus threatened my life!
What do I care for your life when set against the game?!
Enough. Do you concede defeat?
Never.
Then you leave me no choice. The detonator -
HE LIFTS IT. PEABODY DIVES AT HIM.

DOCTOR: Oh, I’ve seen it all before. Again and again. A petty despot with a desire to take over the world, the galaxy, the universe! You’re nothing special. Doing all this because of an insatiable lust for power! A thirst for conquest! A desire to dominate!

DOCTOR: (UTTER SURPRISE) A what?!
QUEEN: (SIMPLY) A bet. A wager with my brother.

MARJORIE: (TAKING IT IN) A bet...
QUEEN: My family is known as The Contingency. A race of game players. We have played for several worlds in our time.

DOCTOR: #222: THE CONTINGENCY CLUB by Phil Mulryne (FINAL) Page 131
QUEEN: Oh, but a very special one. My brother wagered I could not take it without superior technology. I disagreed. I said cunning and tactics alone could sway any game.
